facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 195 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 195 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 3, 1957, of the Patna High Court in Appeal from original decree No. 42 of 1948.

facts.text: Appeal from Patna High Court judgment and decree dated September 3, 1957 in Appeal from original decree No. 42 of 1948.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 195 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 3, 1957, of the Patna High Court in Appeal from original decree No. 42 of 1948.

facts.text: Suit land is about 14 bighas and 5 kathas in khata No.741 in mauza Chaugain.

anchor.surface_text: The subject matter of the suit is a piece of land of about 14 bighas and 5 kathas in khata No.741 in mauza Chaugain.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed declaration that land is zeraiti land and recovery of possession from defendants 1st and 2nd parties.

anchor.surface_text: The relief claimed in the suit was a declaration that the land referred to was the zeraiti land of the plaintiffs and that the persons who were impleaded as the defendants 1st and 2nd parties had no right or title thereto and for recovery of possession of the said land by dispossessing the defendants who were in actual possession thereof.

facts.text: Plaintiffs' ancestors executed registered rehan bond on October 28, 1897 including suit lands to ancestors of defendants 3rd parties.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs ancestors had executed a registered rehan bond on October 28, 1897 of lands including those in suit, in favour of the ancestors of the persons who were impleaded as defendants 3rd parties.

facts.text: Plaintiffs' ancestors executed another registered rehan bond in June 1907 to ancestors of defendants 4th parties, who redeemed the 1897 mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: During the subsistence of this mortgage the plaintiffs ancestors executed another registered rehan bond .in June, 1907 in favour of persons who were the ancestors of the persons impleaded as defendants 4th parties, a portion of the mortgage money being left with these second mortgagees to enable them to redeem the earlier mortgage.

facts.text: On June 8, 1941, plaintiffs paid off the 1907 rehan bond and endorsed satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: On June 8, 1941, the plaintiffs paid off the amount due on the rehan bond of 1907 and entered satisfaction on the bond making an endorsement thereon.

facts.text: After redemption on June 8, 1941, plaintiffs obtained possession of portion but not suit lands, held by defendants 1st and 2nd parties claiming occupancy rights.

anchor.surface_text: On such redemption the plaintiffs obtained possession of a portion of the lands under mortgage but they could not obtain possession of the lands in suit. These lands were in the possession of the defendants 1st and 2nd parties who claimed title on the basis of their being entitled to occupancy rights in the lands

facts.text: Defendants 1st and 2nd parties claimed suit lands as raiyati lands with occupancy rights.

anchor.surface_text: and they refused to surrender actual possession of the land to the plaintiffs. They had asserted that the suit lands were not zeraiti lands in regard to which the plaintiff as maliks would be entitled to khas possession, but were raiyat- lands from which they, the tenants in cultivation could not be evicted.

facts.text: Trial court decreed suit on October 10, 1947: land zeraiti of plaintiffs, defendants entered possession under 1906 lease expiring 1912-13, adverse possession from 1941, suit within time.

anchor.surface_text: On these findings the learned trial judge, by his judgment dated October 10, 1947, decreed the suit, as prayed for.

facts.text: Defendants 2nd party appealed to Patna High Court, obtained stay of possession.

anchor.surface_text: The contesting defendants-defendants 2nd party filed an appeal to the High Court challenging these findings. Pending the appeal they applied for and obtained stay of delivery of possession

facts.text: Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 came into force on September 25, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: While the appeal was pending the Bihar Land Reforms Act (Act XXX of 1950) was enacted and it came into force on September 25, 1950.

facts.text: Plaintiffs' estate vested in State as from January 1, 1955 under notification under s.3(1) of Bihar Land Reforms Act.

anchor.surface_text: Under a notification published under s. 3(1) of the Act the plaintiffs estate became vested, as and from January 1, 1955, in the State.

facts.text: Patna High Court in September 1957 upheld trial court findings on zeraiti nature but set aside possession decree due to vesting, allowed mesne profits till 31.12.1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal came on for hearing before the High Court in September, 1957. ... The learned judges therefore examined the oral and documentary evidence bearing upon these points and arrived at the same conclusion as the learned trial judge.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal on certificate under Art. 133(1) by Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: the principal point that arises in this. appeal which is before us on a certificate of fitness granted under Art. 133 (1) by the High Court of Patna.

facts.text: Trial court found land was zeraiti of plaintiffs, not in possession of tenants in 1897.

anchor.surface_text: the findings recorded by him were 1 that the land was the zeraiti land of the plaintiffs and had been in their actual possession and not in the possession of any tenants of theirs at the date of the 1st rehan in 1897.

facts.text: Trial court found defendants came into possession under lease about 1906 for term expiring 1912-13.

anchor.surface_text: 2 the defendants came into possession of the land under a lease deed executed about the year 1906 for a term of years and that that lease deed expired in 1912-13

facts.text: Defendants' possession became adverse only after redemption in June 1941.

anchor.surface_text: their possession could not be adverse to the plaintiffs until the latter got the right to resume possession which was only in June 1941 when they paid and discharged the amount due under the mortgage

facts.text: Defendants claimed possession as tenants 30 years before 1897.

anchor.surface_text: It was the case of the defendants that they had been in possession and occupation of the land as tenants long before the rehan of 1897-even 30 years earlier

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed defendants inducted first as tenants under 1897 mortgage for 7 years expiring 1912-13.

anchor.surface_text: whereas it was the case of the plaintiffs that they were inducted to the land for the first time as tenants of the mortgagees under the first rehan of 1897 and that they were originally brought in as tenants for a term of 7 years which expired in or about 1912-13

facts.text: High Court declined State's request for possession decree due to lack of diligence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges, however, declined this request for the reason that the, State had not been diligent in acting upon the notice served upon them as required by the Act and not entering appearance within the time limited therefore.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered April 25, 1963 by AYYANGAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 25. The judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J.-

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.6(1)(c) does not apply as defendants' possession was adverse and not as mortgagees after 1941 redemption.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6(1)(c) cannot, in terms, therefore apply since the mortgagor-mortgagee relationship did not subsist on.January 1, 1955 even if the construction which learned Counsel for the appellant pressed upon us was accepted.

facts.text: Plaintiffs treated defendants as trespassers after 1941 redemption.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 10 of the plaint reads it is quite clear that the defendants 1st party or 2nd party have no kasht right in the disputed lands as against the plaintiffs, and after redemption of the rehan, their possession and occupation are quite wrongful.

issues.text: The proper construction of the vesting sections of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 and in particular the scope of s. 6 thereof

anchor.surface_text: The proper construction of the vesting sections of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 hereinafter called the Act , and in particular the scope of s. 6 thereof is the principal point that arises in this. appeal

holdings.text: Section 6(1)(c) cannot, in terms, therefore apply since the mortgagor-mortgagee relationship did not subsist on January 1, 1955 even if the construction which learned Counsel for the appellant pressed upon us was accepted.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6(1)(c) cannot, in terms, therefore apply since the mortgagor-mortgagee relationship did not subsist on.January 1, 1955 even if the construction which learned Counsel for the appellant pressed upon us was accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mortgage redeemed in 1941 with satisfaction endorsed; defendants resisted possession asserting independent title as trespassers per plaint; no derivative holding post-redemption.

holdings.text: We consider that this equation of the right to possession with khas possession is not justified by principle or authority.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sarjoo Prasad however relied on certain observations in the judgment of the full Bench of the Patna High Court in Sukdeo Das v. Kashi Prasad were the learned judges appear to consider the possession even of a trespasser who has not perfected his title by adverse possession for the time requisite under the Indian Limitation Act as the khas possession of the true owner. We consider that this equation of the right to possession with khas possession is not justified by principle or authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(k) defines khas possession as actual cultivation by proprietor/servants/hired; constructive possession via trespasser inconsistent with statutory language and Full Bench reasoning.

holdings.text: It is not possible for the appellants to contend that these tenants were in possession of the property on behalf of the mortgagor and in the character of their rights being derived from the mortgagor.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we consider that it is not possible for the appellants to contend that these tenants were in possession of the property on behalf of the mortgagor and in the character of their rights being derived from the mortgagor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaint para 10 admits defendants' post-redemption possession wrongful; resisted entry asserting occupancy rights adverse to both mortgagee and mortgagor; overt acts ended any derivative character.

holdings.text: The possession of the contesting defendants in the present case was in their own right and adverse to the plaintiffs, even on the case with which the appellants themselves came into Court.

anchor.surface_text: The possession of the contesting defendants in the present case was in their own right and adverse to the plaintiffs, even on the case with which the appellants themselves came into Court. The plaintiffs stated in their plaint that the mortgagees had, so far as they were concerned, fulfilled their obligations and had put the mortgagors in possession of such property as they could and that it was the contesting defendants who putting forward claims to occupancy rights, resisted their entry into possession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent lower court findings (zeraiti land, entry under term lease expiring 1912-13, adverse only post-1941 redemption); plaint treats as trespassers; no subsisting mortgage link.

holdings.text: We should, therefore, not be taken to have either affirmed or disagreed with the findings recorded by the learned trial judge and the High Court as regards the zeraiti character of the land and the claim of the defendants 1st and 2nd parties to occupancy rights in those lands.

anchor.surface_text: We should, therefore, not be taken to have either affirmed or disagreed with the findings recorded by the learned trial judge and the High Court as regards the zeraiti character of the land and the claim of the defendants 1st and 2nd parties to occupancy rights in those lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not necessary to decide as s.6 inapplicable even assuming favourably to appellant; no cross-appeal by respondents on declaration/mesne profits.

precedents.citation: Mahanth Sukhdeo Das v. Kashi Prasad Tiwari 1

anchor.surface_text: For this purpose learned Counsel relied on the decision of the Full Bench of the Patna High Court in Mahanth Sukhdeo Das v. Kashi Prasad Tiwari 1 . Where lands in the actual physical possession of one companysharer were held to be in the khas possession of all the companysharers within s. 2 k . 2 it was then urged that where a mortgagee companytinued in possession of property usufructuarily mortgaged to him, even after the mortgage was paid and discharged the property remained in the khas possession of the mortgagor because the mortgagee does number hold the property adversely to the mortgagor but his possession having started permissively, he must in law be deemed to hold it still as mortgagee.

precedents.case_name: Mahanth Sukhdeo Das v. Kashi Prasad Tiwari
precedents.cited_proposition: lands in the actual physical possession of one co-sharer were held to be in the khas possession of all the co-sharers within s. 2(k)

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sarjoo Prasad however relied on certain observations in the judgment of the full Beneh of the Patna High Court in Sukdeo Das v. Kashi Prasad 1 , were the learned judges appear to companysider the possession even of a trespasser who has number perfected his title by adverse possession for the time requisite under the Indian Limitation Act as the khas possession of the true owner. We companysider that this equation of the right to possession with khas possession is number justified by principle or authority.

precedents.cited_proposition: possession even of a trespasser who has perfected title by adverse possession is khas possession of the true owner

anchor.surface_text: A. I. R. 1958 Patna 630, of the companytesting defendants assumes crucial importance, for if they were admittedly trespassers then they companyld number be said to hold the property on behalf of the mortgagors and the entire basis of the argument as to the property being in the khas possession of the plaintiffs would disappear. Paragraph 10 of the plaint reads it is quite clear that the defendants 1st party or 2nd party have numberkasht right in the disputed lands as against the plaintiffs, and after redemption of the rehan, their possession and occupation are quite wrongful.
